https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Test Your Board

This level is just a quick test to make sure your board is working. To run this test, do the following:

1.  Plug your board into your computer with a USB cable
2.  Click "Run"
3.  Wait a few seconds for either a Success or Error screen to pop up
4.  If your test was successful, move on to the next level. If not, try some of the troubleshooting steps

## Troubleshooting

There are a number of things that could prevent your test from passing.

1.  Try refreshing the page and running the test again (you should refresh the page for each of the following ideas as well)
2.  Try connecting your board to a different USB port
3.  Try a different USB cable. Some USB cables can only be used for charging, so make sure your cable supports data transfer!
4.  Try a different board
5.  Go to [studio.code.org/maker/setup][0] to run a more detailed test

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Buzzer Duration

The [`buzzer.frequency()`(#f78183)][0] block has two parameters: frequency and duration.

-   Frequency changes how the buzzer sounds. The bigger the number you give it, the higher the buzzer's sound will be.
-   Duration determines how long the buzzer is going to play a sound for in milliseconds. 1000 milliseconds is the same as 1 second.

You can read more about how the buzzer works by [clicking here][1]. For right now we're going to focus on duration, the second parameter.

## Do this

1.  Drag out a frequency block to each of the events
2.  Change the second parameter so the buttons play sounds for different lengths

# Correct & Incorrect

Sounds can be used to cue the user if they get something correct or incorrect.

## Do this

1.  Decide which of the answers is “correct” based on your preferences.
2.  Add a frequency block to make a high-pitched sound if someone picks that option.
3.  Add frequency blocks to the other events for when someone picks an incorrect answer.

**Run your code!** Test out the app with a neighbor to see if they guess the correct answer.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions: # Virtual Monster Pet Eva is trying to make an app that simulates a virtual monster pet. The LED represents the monster's eye, and the buzzer will be the noises that it makes. The app lets you control the emotions of the monster in the following way: - When you press the Happy button, the pet should stare at you without blinking and make a mid-pitched squeal - When you press the Nervous button, the pet should blink quickly and make a short, high-pitched squeal - When you press the Sleepy button, the pet should close it’s eye and make a long, low growl (like it’s snoring) The Happy button has already been coded - we need to add the code for the other two buttons ## Do This 1. Add code to the Nervous button so it blinks quickly and makes a short, high-pitched squeal 2. Add code to the Sleepy button so it closes its eye and makes a long, low growl (like it's snoring)

This app mimics an "I Spy" childrens app. ## Do This 1) Choose one of the food images to be your secret image. 2) Using the existing [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) as an example, add a new [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) that detects when the use moves their mouse over your secret image. 3) Inside the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/), add code so the red LED lights up **Run Your Code!** You should be able to move the mouse around the screen, and the LED will light up only when it hovers over your secret image.

CSD U6 - Board Outputs - ChalC_2222.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to use the random number block to make the buzzer play a random frequency
CSD U6 - Board Outputs - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
# Random Buzzer!

Create an app with a single button. When the user presses the button, the buzzer will play a random frequency for a random amount of time. This app requires you to use the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/applab/randomNumber_min_max/) block.

## Do This:
**In Design Mode:** 
1) Drag out a button element and give it a descriptive ID

**In Code Mode:**

2) Add an [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) block for when the user clicks the button
3) Use the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/applab/randomNumber_min_max/) block inside the [`buzzer.frequency()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/buzzer.frequency/) block to play a random frequency for a random duration

**Run Your Code!** When you press the button, the buzzer should make a different sound each time!

CSD U6 - Board Outputs - ChalD_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that could be used in an educational setting
CSD U6 - Board Outputs - ChalD_2222.long_instructions:
# Education App

Create an app that uses the buzzer or LED that could be used in an educational setting. For example, your app could ask the user to solve a problem or answer a question and then buzz or blink if they get it correct or incorrect.

You may not be able to create the "perfect" app yet, but you can develop a **prototype** which shows the general idea of the app and some of the basic features behind how it could work.
CSD U6 - Board Outputs - ChalD_2222.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a **focused free-play** level: students are free to design an app based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their app, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop an app of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Changing Properties

The [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][0] block can be used to change lots of things about your design elements. We'll practice using [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][1] to update the look of a welcome screen for an app.

_Note: We've removed the Design Mode tab for now so you can practice working with `setProperty`, but it'll come back later once you're building apps of your own._

# Do This

1.  Look at the [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][2] block that is already in the code. This block updates the font used in the title.
2.  Use another [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][3] block to update the background color of the title
    -   For the first parameter, select "title" (the element's id)
    -   For the second parameter, select "background-color" (the property you want to set)
    -   For the third parameter, type in a color you would like to use. Make sure your color is in quotes.

(Optional) Add more [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][4] blocks to update the look of your app

# Changing Text

You can also change the text of elements on the screen using the [`setText()`(#fff176)][0] block. Let's update the app so it uses your name in the app.

_Note: We've removed the Design Mode tab for now so you can practice working with `setProperty` and `setText`, but it'll come back later once you're building apps of your own._

## Do This

1.  Use a [`setText()`(#fff176)][1] block to update the app to display your name
    -   Drag out a [`setText()`(#fff176)][2] block
    -   For the first parameter, select "nameLabel" (the element's id)
    -   For the second parameter, type in your name using quotes

(Optional) Use [`setText()`(#fff176)][3] to change the greeting as well - for example, changing it to "Howdy" or "Hola" or "你好"

# Changing Position Every design element (except for the screen) has an "x" and a "y" property that controls its position. We can use these properties to re-position elements on the screen. The App Lab screen is 320 pixels wide and 450 pixels tall. _Note: We've removed the Design Mode tab for now so you can practice working with setProperty, but it'll come back later once you're building apps of your own._ # Do This
[expandable][0]
1. Look at the image to the right (click to see the image in full size). We want to make our app match this picture 2. Look at the example code that moves the `greenButton` to the upper-right corner 3. Move "redButton" so it is in the upper-left corner - Use two [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][1] blocks to change the `x` and `y` properties of the `"redButton"` element

# Changing With a Click

It's not really useful to only set a property when your program is first run. After all, you could just do all of that in Design Mode. When you use an [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0] block with [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][1], you're able to do things you couldn't do with Design Mode alone.

In this example, let's move the smiley icon to the center of the screen when it's clicked

## Do This

1.  When you click the smiley, move it to the center of the screen
    -   Inside the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][2] block: 
        -   use two [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][3] blocks to move the smiley to the center of the screen.
        -   You'll need to update the `x` and `y` properties of the smiley icon.

**Run Your Code!** Click the smiley and watch it move to the center of the screen!

# Randomization Moving on the first click is fine, but this smiley would be even cooler if it moved somewhere new _every time_ we clicked. Fortunately, we can use the [`randomNumber`(#FFB74D)][0] block to do just that. ## Do This 1. Edit your code so it uses the [`randomNumber`(#FFB74D)][1] block inside the [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][2] blocks for the `x` and `y` properties. 2. Change the start and end values of [`randomNumber`(#FFB74D)][3] so the smiley will jump across the whole screen - _Tip: The App Lab screen is 320 pixels wide by 450 pixels tall._ **Run your code!** Every time you click the smiley, it should jump to a new random location

# Visibility Design elements can be hidden from the user using the [`hideElement()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/hideElement/) block, and then re-appear using the [`showElement()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/showElement/) block. We are going to use these blocks to create an alarm app. We have already set up an [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) for the `triggerAlarmButton` which will do three things when clicked: * Set the text of `statusLabel` to "On" * Hides the `triggerAlarmButton`, since we just turned the alarm on * Shows the `stopAlarmButton`, so the user has the option to turn off the alarm But, the app is not finished - pressing the `stopAlarmButton` doesn't actually turn off the alarm. ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) Run the program and click "Trigger Alarm" to see how it works 2) ::: details [Using `triggerAlarmButton` as a model, add code so that pressing `stopAlarmButton` resets the alarm] - Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the `statusLabel` to "Off" - Use [`hideElement()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/hideElement/) to hide the `stopAlarmButton` - Use [`showElement()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/showElement/) to show the `triggerAlarmButton` :::

CSD U6 - Screen Outputs - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
# Theme Designer

Some app editors let you add themes to a design, which updates all of the labels and buttons on the screen. In this app, we're creating our own theme designer that we can use to test out different themes.

An example theme has already been coded, which updates the properties of the `label` and `button` on the screen. Your task is to design your own theme that updates the look of the app.

## Do This

1) Add code to the `myTheme` button that updates the look of the `screen1`, `label`, and `button` elements on the screen

# Emoji Reactions Make an app that starts with a neutral emoji on the screen. When the user presses `down` the left button, it changes to a happy face. When the user presses `down` the right button, it changes to a sad face. When the user lets `up` either button, it changes back to a neutral face. ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) :::details [When the user presses the left button, show a happy face] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the user presses `"down"` on `buttonL`. - Use a [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) block to update the `image` of the emoji to a happy face (`icon://fa-smile-o`) ::: 2) ::: details [When the user presses the right button, show a sad face] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the user presses `"down"` on `buttonR`. - Use a [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) block to update the `image` of the emoji to a frown face (`icon://fa-frown-o`) ::: 3) ::: details [When a user releases the left button, show a neutral face] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the user presses `"up"` on `buttonL`. - Use a [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) block to update the `image` of the emoji to a neutral face (`icon://fa-meh-o`) ::: 4) ::: details [When the user releases the right button, show a neutral face] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the user presses `"up"` on `buttonR`. - Use a [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) block to update the `image` of the emoji to a neutral face (`icon://fa-meh-o`) ::: **Run Your Code!** When you hold a button, the emoji should change to a happy or sad emoji. When you release the button, it should change back to the neutral emoji.

# LED Blinker Create an app that simulates a blinker like on a car or bicycle. When the user slides the toggle switch open, the LED should start blinking. When the user slides the toggle switch closed, the LED should stop. ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [When the toggle switch is open, blink the LED] - Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) to detect when the `toggleSwitch` is `open` - Make the LED blink every 500 milliseconds ::: 2) ::: details [When the toggle switch is closed, stop the LED from blinking] - Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) to detect when the `toggleSwitch` is `closed` - Stop the LED from blinking ::: **Run the app!** You should be able to make the LED start blinking by turning the toggle switch, then stop the LED by moving it to the opposite direction

CSD U6 - Board Inputs - PracD_2222.bubble_choice_description: Use buttons and buzzing frequencies to simulate Morse Code
CSD U6 - Board Inputs - PracD_2222.long_instructions: # Morse Code Simulator [Morse Code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morse_code) is a system for communicating that uses long and short beeps to represent letters. Create an app that uses the buttons to play beeps for morse code - the left button should play short beeps, and the right button should play long beeps ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [When the left button is pressed, play a short buzz] - Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) to check when `buttonL` goes `down`. - Play the buzzer for `100` milliseconds ::: 2) ::: details [When the right button is pressed, play a long buzz] - Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) to check when `buttonR` goes `down`. - Play the buzzer for `300` milliseconds ::: **Run the app!** Use the chart on the right to try and send the message "CS" or to spell your initials

CSD U6 - Board Inputs - PracE_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app that uses button presses and the buzzer to communicate "yes" and "no" answers
CSD U6 - Board Inputs - PracE_2222.long_instructions:
# Yes-Or-No Communicator

Create an app that uses the buzzer and the left and right buttons to represent answers to yes or no questions. For example, a high-buzz could represent "yes" and a low-buzz could represent "no". Then, use the buzzer to answer yes-or-no questions with a partner and see if they can understand your responses!

## Do This

**In Design Mode:**
- Decide on what buzz represents "yes" and what buzz represents "no"
- Use a `label` element to describe what type of buzz means "yes" and what type of buzz means "no"
	- For example: "A high-pitched buzz is yes" or "A short buzz is yes"

**In Code Mode:**

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [When the user presses the left button, respond with "yes"]
	- Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) to detect when the `left` button is pressed `down`
	- Play the buzzer in a way that represents "yes"
    :::
2) ::: details [When the user presses the right button, respond with "no"]
	- Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) to detect when the `right` button is pressed `down`
	- Play the buzzer in a way that represents "no"
    :::

**Run The App!** When a partner looks at the app, they should be able to understand how it works without you needing to speak. When they ask yes-or-no questions, they should be able to understand your answers without you needing to speak either!

_Note: This is an example of an app that focuses on **accessibility**, which makes it easier for people with disabilities to use technology and communicate. This type of app could be used by someone who can't speak but still needs to communicate_

# Mood Descriptor

Angel is working on an app that lets them communicate their current mood to a screen that can hang outside their door before anyone enters their room. From inside their room, Angel can press buttons on the Circuit Playground, which updates the app on the outside of their room.

1.  Closing the toggle-switch shows a happy emoji (`icon://fa-smile-o`)
2.  Opening the toggle-switch right shows a sad emoji (`icon://fa-frown-o`)
3.  Pressing the right button makes the emoji large (200 x 200 pixels), as if to say they are very happy or very sad
4.  Pressing the left button makes the emoji small (100 x 100 pixels), as if to say they are kind of happy or kind of sad

The app has already been started for you, but it's missing all of the inputs for when Angel uses their Circuit Playground!

## Do This

-   Update the code to match the app above

# Day and Night Use design mode to create two scenes representing daytime and nighttime. Several assets have already been provided in this level, but you can also search for more on the internet. Add code so when the toggle switch is open, the scene is during the day. But when the toggle switch is closed, the scene is at night. contained levels.long_instructions:
# Prediction

The code below has a new block called `var`. Read the code below, then make a prediction for what will happen on the screen when the code is run. What do you think will happen to the rectangles?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions: # Creating a Checkerboard The `var` block is short for **variable**, which can store a value to be used throughout your code. For example, if you wanted a lot of objects to have the same color, you could set the color to a **variable** and then re-use that variable every time you wanted to use that color. Let's use this idea to create a checkerboard on the screen with alternating colors. ## Do This 1. Look at the top of the code which has several `var` blocks 2. Edit the colors and numbers on the right-side of the blocks to make the app match the picture to the right - You should only need to change the colors and numbers - you won't need to add any new blocks to your code!

# Editing Variables

Variables can be used to store information. This can be useful if you want to update multiple things with the same value.

In this example, Amy wrote a program that creates a shadow text effect under her name using multiple text labels. She's using a variable to update each text label with the same name, but there's a bug in her code - one of the labels isn't updating correctly.

## Do This

-   Run the code to see what's happening. You should notice one of the labels isn't updating like the others
-   Look at the code and try to determine which label is incorrect, then update it to use the `myName` variable correctly
-   Replace Amy's name with your name and see the result!

# Using Variables

You can create a variable using the [`var`(#BB77C7)][0] block. Let's create a variable for the y-position of each rectangle and use it to update the screen. The code has already been started - you need to finish it!

## Do This

1.  Create a variable and assign it a value
    -   Drag out a [`var`(#BB77C7)][1] block and give it a label on the left-side of the equal sign
    -   On the right side of the equal sign, type in a number between 0 and 450
2.  Update the [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][2] blocks so they use your new variable in the last position

**Run the code!** You should see all of the blocks snap together on the same horizontal line! Try re-running the program with different values to see how the image changes.

# Counting Presses

Eric is creating a program where pressing the left button adds 1 to the value on the screen, and pressing the right button subtracts 1 from the value on the screen. This is sometimes called the **[Counter Pattern][0]**. 

The left button has already been coded - can you update the right button to work correctly too?

## Do This

-   Update the `counter` variable to subtract by 1 when the right button is pressed
    -   ::: details [**Show Me How**]
        -   Find the section that says `Add your code here!`
        -   Drag out a `x = ;`(#BB77C7) block
        -   Replace the `x` with the variable name: `value`
        -   Drag out a `-`(#FFB74D) block
        -   On the left side of the `-`(#FFB74D), type the variable name: `value`
        -   On the right side of the `-`(#FFB74D), type `1`
            :::

# Changing Positions

The **[Counter Pattern][0]** can also be used to change the position of elements on the screen. Let's make a program where pressing the left button moves the bird up, and pressing the right button moves the bird down

_Note: Remember that y positions are reversed on the screen. Moving up means subtracting, and moving down means adding_

## Do This

1.  Inside the `buttonL` event, subtract one from the `yPosition` variable
    -   Run your code and test that the bird is able to move up!
2.  Inside the `buttonR` event, add one to the `yPosition` variable
    -   Run your program and test that the bird is able to move up and down!

Optional: try changing the amount that the bird changes on each button press. This can simulate moving at different speeds!

Students should also notice that the background changes between two different colors - orange and gray. Connecting these two observations together, students might predict that this will change when the "sun sets" behind the horizon, changing colors between day (orange) and night (gray).

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Increasing Text

This app is meant to simulate someone whispering for you to come closer, only to surprise you with a loud noise. It uses the **[Counter Pattern][0]** to increase the size of the text on the screen. Once the text reaches 30 pixels, the text should change to "SURPRISE!" and a sound from the buzzer should play.

## Do This

1.  Add an [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][1] to your code to check when the `textSize` variable is greater than 30
    -   ::: details [**Show Me How**]
        -   Find the section that says `Add your code here!`
        -   Drag out a [`if statement`(#64B5F6)][2] block
        -   Drag out a `>`(#FFB74D) block
        -   On the left side of the `>`(#FFB74D), type the variable name: `textSize`
        -   On the right side of the `>`(#FFB74D), type `30`
            :::
2.  When it is: change the text of the label to "SURPRISE!" and play a sound on the buzzer using [`buzzer.frequency`(#f78183)][3].
    -   ::: details [**Show Me How**]
        -   Inside the [`if statement`(#64B5F6)][4]:
            -   Drag out a [`setText()`(#fff176)][5] and update the `textLabel` element to say "Surprise!"
            -   Drag out a [`buzzer.frequency`(#f78183)][6] block to play a sound
                :::

# Perfect Toast

This app simulates a toaster with a piece of toast in between two heated sides. The toast needs to be perfectly placed in the middle - if it's too close to one of the sides, the toast will burn! We can help alert the user of the burning toast by using the buzzer to make a noise if the toast is too close to the edges. Then the user can press buttons on the toaster to move the toast closer to the center.

## Do This:

1.  If the toast is too far to the left, play a sound to alert the user
    -   Add an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)][0] to the `buttonL` event to check if the toast is too far to the left.
    -   Use the the [`buzzer.frequency`(#f78183)][1] block to play a sound and let the user know
2.  If the toast is too far to the right, play a sound to alert the user
    -   Add an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)][2] to the `buttonR` event to check if the toast is too far to the right.
    -   Use the the [`buzzer.frequency`(#f78183)][3] block to play a sound and let the user know

**Run Your Code!** Use the left and right buttons to reposition the toast. When the toast gets too close to the walls, the device should buzz!

# Positivity App

Hawa is making a positivity app where people can track good deeds or positive statements they make throughout the day by pressing a button on the Circuit Playground. Each time they press a button, the heart grows a little bit in size. When the heart fills the box, the circuit playground should buzz.

Hawa has already started the app, but needs help adding the variables and if-statements to her code.

# Do This

-   Add a variable called `size` as the first line of your code and set it to `30` ( [Show me where][0] )
-   Add code inside your event that increases the `size` variable by 20 each time a button is pressed ( [Show me where][1] )
-   Add an if-statement that checks when the heart has reached a size of at least 300 pixels ( [Show me where][2] )
-   Inside the if-statement: Have the buzzer make a noise to let the user know they're reached their goal

# Water Level App Create an app that simulates an automatic bathtub filler, where the water level rises to a set point. You should use the left button to raise the water, and the right button to lower the water. When the water goes past the black line of the bathtub, the Circuit Playground should buzz to let you know you're at risk of overflowing! ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [When the left button is pressed, the water rises up the screen] - Use the [Counter Pattern](/docs/concepts/patterns/counter-patterns-with-event/) to change the `waterY` variable. Don't forget: moving up means subtracting so the y position gets smaller - Use [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) to update the y position of the water image ::: 2) ::: details [If the water gets to the black line, the circuit playground should buzz] - Add an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the waterY variable. - If it's above the black line: have the Circuit Playground buzz! ::: 3) ::: details [When the right button is pressed, the water lowers on the screen] - Use the [Counter Pattern](/docs/concepts/patterns/counter-patterns-with-event/) to change the `waterY` variable. Don't forget: moving down means adding so the y position gets smaller - Use [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) to update the y position of the water image :::

It can be music or movies or books or foods or places to visit - whatever you decide. **In Design Mode:** 2) Change to one of the other choice screens (for example: `choice1Screen`), then add labels or images representing this choice 3) Repeat this process for each of the four screens **In Code Mode:** _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 4) ::: details [When the + button is pressed: have it increase the age on the screen by 1] - Use the [Counter Pattern](/docs/concepts/patterns/counter-patterns-with-event/) to add 1 to the age variable - Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the `ageLabel` ::: 5) ::: details [When the - button is pressed: have it decrease the age on the screen by 1] - Use the [Counter Pattern](/docs/concepts/patterns/counter-patterns-with-event/) to subtract 1 to the age variable - Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the `ageLabel` ::: 6) ::: details [When the "Recommend" button is pressed: have it go to a certain screen based on the user's age] - Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the value of the age variable - Use the [`setScreen(screenId)`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setScreen/) block to change to a specific screen based on their age - Repeat this four times for each screen :::

# Debugging: Infinite Scrolling
![expandable](https://images.code.org/4a82e91b1b6ad15623620fee4383c964-image-1648759745413.gif)
Click to Expand
This app is meant to move an arrow across the screen. When the arrow reaches the edge of the screen, it should reset back to the beginning - but, something's wrong! - **What I Expected to Happen:** When the arrow reaches the far sides, it teleports to the other side so it can keep moving - **What Actually Happens:** The arrow moves just once, sometimes off of the screen _Note: you may need to switch into text mode to fix this bug_ (Optional) Even when the bug is fixed, the infinite scroll doesn't look great. Can you adjust the numbers so the scrolling effect looks smoother?
CSD U6 - If Variables - ChalE_2222.teacher_markdown:
The bug is that the `>` and `<` symbols are swapped in the if-statements. For example, the top if statement checks if `xPos < 320`, which will be true while the arrow is still on the screen. We want the opposite: `xPos > 320`. This correctly checks that the arrow is off of the right-side of the screen. Similarly, the second if statement should be checking that `xPos < 0`.

Students can fix this within block mode, but it's a little tedious and requires removing the `<` and `>` blocks completely. It can be easier to switch into text mode and manually change these symbols, then switch back to block mode. For some students, this can be a good excuse to try out text mode if they've never used it before.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Design Your App

Use this level to add **design elements** to your app in Design Mode. Use the sketch from your Project Guide to add elements to the screen. Don't worry about adding code yet - you can do that in the next few levels.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Events

Add events to your app using [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0] or [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][1] blocks. Include other blocks that will let you test your events to make sure they are working correctly, such as changing the screen or making a small buzz on the circuit playground. Don't worry about any variables or if-statements for right now - you can do that in the next level.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Logic

Add the core logic to your app, using [`variables`(#BB77C7)][0] and [`if statements`(#64B5F6)][1]. Use your project guide to help complete your code. Test your app several times to see that it behaves as expected. 

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Review Your App

Take a moment to review your app. Double-check that it meets all the requirements in the rubric - [click here to see the rubric][0]. Make any changes or updates you think are necessary, or you may decide that the app is fine.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then the purple Submit button to submit your project. Once you submit it, you won't be able to edit it.

CSD U6 - Color LEDs - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
# Mood Lights

Create an app prototype where your circuit playground could be used to create mood lighting in a room. This is similar to many commercial products where a remote control can change the colors of an LED light bulb to suit different moods.

Your app should have at least 3 buttons on the screen representing different moods (like "excited" or "calm" or "anxious" or "tranquil"). When the user presses one of these buttons on your app, the LEDs should light up to match the mood. Optionally, you could also have the background of the app change to a picture that matches the mood.

CSD U6 - Color LEDs - ChalD_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that can communicate long distances using the color LEDs.
CSD U6 - Color LEDs - ChalD_2222.long_instructions:
# Long-Distance Signal Create an app prototype that can communicate long distances using the color LEDs. This involves coming up with a visual code for certain words or phrases, sharing that code with a partner, then using that code to communicate. For this example, imagine you needed to communicate directions across a long distance or across the classroom. ::: details [**Wait - is this a real thing? Click here to find out**]
![expandable](https://images.code.org/c31a064979cf7d45566264b26db5e81b-image-1646099374771.png)
Click to Expand
Before the invention of the telephone or even the telegram, people used symbols and visuals to communicate long distances. These methods were especially useful on ships that were traveling together and needed to communicate across the water. A common system was to use flags to symbol letters and numbers to neighboring ships. [Click here to learn more about this system](https://www.britannica.com/technology/semaphore) ::: ## Do This **Planning:** 1) Decide on an LED pattern to represent `North`, `South`, `East`, and `West`. You could use different colors, or turn some LEDs on and leave others off, or come up with completely unique patterns for each direction. You may want to draw a picture to represent your pattern, since you will be sharing it with a partner **In Code Mode:** 2) Add code to each of the buttons to match the pattern you decided on above **Run Your Code:** 3) Have a partner stand across the room with the code that you created. Set some obstacles in the way that they will need to avoid. 4) Run the app and give your partner directions using the color LEDs 5) Guide them to cross the room and avoid the obstacles

# Baby Sleep Light

Create an app prototype where your circuit playground could be used to create a baby sleep light, which is a night light that also plays soothing sounds or music to help a baby go to sleep.

Your app should use the screen to turn the night light on or off. When the device is on, it should show low lighting and play soothing music or sounds to help a baby go to sleep. When the device is off, the lights and music should turn off.

# Get and Set Text

This app simulates a temperature sensor in certain rooms of the house. You can customize the welcome screen by entering your name and the room of the house that the sensor is in. This app uses a variable and [`getText()`(#fff176)][0] block to get the users name, then a [`setText()`(#fff176)][1] block to update the screen. However, the second input box isn't setup correctly.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions: # Dropdowns You can also use a dropdown to let the user interact with the screen. A dropdown lets you select from a list of options. You can use the [`getProperty()`(#fff176)][0] block to get the `value` from the dropdown and use it in your app. This app should let the user change the background color of the app, but it isn't finished. ## Do This 1. Get the value from the dropdown - Add a [`var x`(#BB77C7)][1] and [`getProperty()`(#fff176)][2] block to get the `value` from the `colorDropdown` element 2. Update the background color - Add a [`setProperty`(#fff176)][3] block to update the background of the screen to the value from the dropdown ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: **Run the program!** Change the background color, then click the update button to see the background change.

# Dropdowns You can also edit the dropdown list of options from design mode. For example, you could update the color choices to match two opposing sports teams or the school logo colors. ## Do This **In Design Mode:** 1. Select the dropdown element and change the colors in the `options` area. - For example: colors that match what you're wearing today, or colors that match different sports teams - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: You do not need to make any changes to your code! **Run Your Program!** The background should should change to the colors you set in design mode

# Sliders

Sliders let you change values in a range, like when you want to give a rating to something. You can use the same [`getProperty()`(#fff176)][0] block to get the `value` from a slider.

This app uses two sliders to change the width and height of an image. Right now, only the width is working. Add code to adjust the height of the image too.

## Do This

1.  Get the value from the slider and store it in a variable
    -   Add a [`var x`(#BB77C7)][1] and [`getProperty()`(#fff176)][2] block to get the `value` from the `heightSlider` element
2.  Update the height of the image on the screen
    -   Add a [`setProperty`(#fff176)][3] block to update the `height` of the image

**Run Your Code!** You might notice that the image doesn't get very large. In the next level, we'll see how you can change the minimum and maximum values for sliders.

[expandable][0]
Click to Expand
# Sliders You can use Design Mode to change the minimum and maximum values for your sliders. ## Do This **In Design Mode:** 1. Click on the `widthSlider` element and find the **maximum value** property. Change the value from 50 to 300. 2. Click on the `heightSlider` element and find the **maximum value** property. Change the value from 50 to 300. **Run the app!** The image should now be able to grow much larger than before

# Sliders Sliders can also be attached to events so you can see the screen update as the slider moves. This uses the new `input` event, which detects when the slider changes as the user moves it. ## Do This 1. As the `widthSlider` updates, change the width of the image - Drag out a new [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0] block. Change the element to `widthSlider` and the event type to `input`. - Copy all of the code from the `updateButton` event into this new event. You may need to switch into text mode. - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: 2. Run the code and verify that changing the slider width will change the image on the screen 3. Drag out a new [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][1] block and repeat these steps for the `heightSlider` element

# Story Generator Create an app that lets the user generate a unique story by entering different words to be used in the story. These are sometimes called "Mad-Libs". In our version, the story will have 3 parts and each part will end with one of the words that the user supplied. For example, one part of the story could say "The disease had spread to all of the fruits and vegetables, turning them all `______`", and then the user enters a color to fill in the missing word. The app has already been started for you with the design and buttons, but it still needs to be filled in with a story and updated based on what the user enters. ## Do This **Planning:** - Think of a 3-part story where each part ends with a word that the user can enter. For example, you can ask the user to enter a type of food, or a place to visit, or someone's name, or a way to describe something. Then each part of your story should end with one of these words **In Design Mode:** - On the `homeScreen`, update each of the `placeholder` properties of the input elements to tell the user what to enter. For example: "Enter a color" or "Enter a name". - Update each of the labels on `part1Screen`, `part2Screen`, and `part3Screen` with the parts of your story **In Code Mode:** - Inside the `startButton` [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/): use variables and [`getText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/getText/) blocks to get the values from each text input, then use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the labels on each screen **Run Your Code!** You should be able to generate a unique story with different words that the user enters _Optional: Add images or colors to your screens to make the story come to life!_

CSD U6 - Screen Inputs - ChalG_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that could be used to order a product from a store, such as ordering groceries online or ordering school supplies from a local business.
CSD U6 - Screen Inputs - ChalG_2222.long_instructions:
# Order Form App

Create an app prototype that could be used to order a product from a store, such as ordering groceries online or ordering school supplies from a local business. The app can use dropdowns and sliders to let the user select what they would like to order, and show a confirmation screen when the order is complete.

You may not be able to create the "perfect" app yet, but you can develop a **prototype** which shows the general idea of the app and some of the basic features behind how it could work.
CSD U6 - Screen Inputs - ChalG_2222.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a **focused free-play level**: students are free to design an app based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their app, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop an app of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

Create an app prototype that could be used for a survey to learn more about a person, such as asking about someone's interests to make a restaurant recommendation or asking about someone's preferences to help a group make a decision.

You may not be able to create the "perfect" app yet, but you can develop a **prototype** which shows the general idea of the app and some of the basic features behind how it could work.

# Debugging

This program is supposed to control the LED and buzzer, but it has some problems. See if you can debug the code to make it work correctly!

You only need to update the code that's already in this level - you don't need to add any new code!

## Do This

1) Turning on the LED
	- **What I Expected To Happen:** Selecting an option from the dropdown and opening the toggle switch will update the red LED
	- **What Happened Instead:** Not all of the options are working correctly
2) Turning off the LED
	- **What I Expected To Happen:** Closing the toggle switch turns off the red LED
	- **What Happened Instead:** The LED seems to turn off even when it's not supposed to
3) Controlling the Buzzer
	- **What I Expected To Happen:** Pressing the left button plays the buzzer according to the sliders
	- **What Happened Instead:** It doesn't sound like the buzzer is playing according to the settings I have
CSD U6 - Combine Inputs - CA_2022.teacher_markdown:
**1) Turning on the LED** - Students need to update the `"Blink"` if-statement to be lowercase instead of uppercase

**2) Turning off the LED** - Students need to update the `onBoardEvent` to use the `closed` event instead of the `change` event

**3) Controlling the Buzzer** - Students need to switch the sliders that the variables are using so they match correctly (ie: the `duration` variable's `getProperty` also uses the `duration` slider)

CSD U6 - Combine Inputs - ChalA_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that simulates a Mood Ring, which changes the colors of the LEDs based on the mood of the user
CSD U6 - Combine Inputs - ChalA_2222.long_instructions:
![expandable](https://images.code.org/cce9c3a7723586f2fc4d590843dc1d2a-image-1648843035099.8.a-finished.gif)
Click to Expand
# LED Mood Ring A [Mood Ring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_ring) is a piece of jewelry with a stone that can change color based on your "mood" (but really, it changes color based on temperature). These were popular gift items in the 1980's since the ring could change color based on the user. Create an app that lets the user select a mood from a dropdown, then updates the ring of lights to match the mood. You can use some [suggested colorings based on actual Mood Rings](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/87/Mood_Stone_User_Guide.png), or make your own decisions about which colors or designs represent certain moods. Your app should have 4 moods. Two moods - `relaxed` and `excited` have already been created for you, and you need to add two more moods. You can also add more options to the dropdown and make as many moods as you want! ## Do This **Planning:** - Decide the other moods you would like to include in your app - Decide which colors or designs you would like to use to represent each mood **Design Mode:** - Add your other moods to the dropdown menu so there are at least four options **Code Mode:** - Add [`if statements`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the value of the dropdown and update the color LEDs. You will need at least four if-statements for each mood. **Run Your Code!** - Have a partner try out your app. They can pick a mood without you seeing the app and only looking at the Circuit Playground. See if you can tell their mood based only on the lights and design of the LEDs.

start_html.Choose your mood from the dropdown below: Choose your mood from the dropdown below and the LED ring will update to reflect it

# Motorcycle Movement

Create an app that moves a motorcycle left and right on the screen using the buttons on the circuit playground. The app has already been started for you: pressing the left button will move the motorcycle to the left by 10 units. CSD U6 - Combine Inputs - ChalC_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app that asks the user a trivia question, then uses the circuit playground to celebrate when they get the answer correct
CSD U6 - Combine Inputs - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
# Trivia Question

Create an app that asks the user a trivia question and lets them type in their response. If they answer correctly, the circuit playground should light up and buzz. If they answer incorrectly, nothing should happen.

## Do This

**Planning:**

- Decide on a trivia question you would like to ask the user. Make sure your question has one clear answer!

**Design Mode:**

- Edit the label to display your trivia question

**Code Mode:**

1) Use a variable and [`getProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/getProperty/) block to get the value from the answer input box
2) Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check if the user entered the correct answer. If they did, have the circuit playground buzz and turn on the LEDs

**Run Your Code!** See if a partner can answer your trivia question!

**Optional Extensions:**

3) Experiment with the `else` part of an `if-statement` to make your program do something if the user answers incorrectly
4) Create a new celebration screen that the user sees when they get the answer correct

start_html.Make sure to enter your answer in all lo: Make sure to enter your answer in all lowercase!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Design Your App

Use this level to add **design elements** to your app in Design Mode. Use the sketch from your Project Guide to add elements to the screen. Don't worry about adding code yet - you can do that in the next few levels.

Whenever you are finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Events

Add events to your app using [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0] or [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][1] blocks. Include other blocks that will let you test your events to make sure they are working correctly, such as changing the screen or making a small buzz on the circuit playground. Don't worry about any variables or if-statements for right now - you can do that in the next level.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Logic and Physical Materials

Add the core logic to your app, especially how your device uses inputs and outputs to function. Also start attaching your board to the physical materials you created. Your device should start to "merge together" with the physical materials you curated, and you may need to make small adjustments so things fit. Use your project guide to help complete your device. Test your app several times to see that it behaves as expected.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Review Your App

Take a moment to review your app. Double-check that it meets all the requirements in the rubric - [click here to see the rubric][0]. Make any changes or updates you think are necessary, or you may decide that the app is fine.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then the purple Submit button to submit your project. Once you submit it, you won't be able to edit it.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.teacher_markdown:
There are three sensors on the circuit playground: a light sensor, a sound sensor, and a temperature sensor. Encourage students to relate the sensors to their own senses and interact with the circuit playground that way - for example, what happens when we show or hide things from the circuit playground? What happens when the volume changes near the circuit playground?

Through experimentation, students should notice that the minimum value is 0 and the maximum value is 1023. Students may also notice that one sensor (temperature) doesn't seem to change very much.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Reading the Sound Sensor

The [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)][0] block allows you to get the current sound sensor reading. In this app we've already added a text label with the id `soundValue`. Using the [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)][1] block, display the value of the sound sensor.

# Do This

1.  When the program starts, update the screen with the sound level near the circuit playground
    -   Drag out a [`setText()`(#fff176)][2] block and set the ID to the label on the screen
    -   Drag out a [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)][3] block directly into the [`setText()`(#fff176)][4] block
        -   ::: details [**Show Me How**]
            [][5]
            :::

**Run Your App! Run it multiple times!** Try running the program multiple times at different volumes. You will need to reset and re-run to have the sensor update. Each time the program is run, it will update the label to display the value from the sound sensor.

# Light Sensor Updates

This app is very similar to the last, but we've added a button with the ID "updateButton". Write a program that displays the current value of the light sensor every time the update button is clicked.

# Do This

1.  Inside the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0] block, update the text of the `lightValue` element using the [`lightSensor.value`(#f78183)][1] block.

**Run Your Code!** Try covering the circuit playground and updating the screen, then try shining a flashlight on the circuit playground and updating the screen!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.teacher_markdown: Students should notice two new blocks in this code - `setScale()` and `onBoardEvent` which refers to the `lightSensor`. Students might predict that something will change on the screen related to the light sensor, but they may not be sure how the board event works. They may notice that `setScale` includes the value 450 which is the height of the screen. Once students run the program and see the emoji moving up and down on the screen, they may be able to make the connection between the scale value and the screen height. It's okay if students still aren't sure about the new board event, since this is introduced in the following level.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Data Event

Each of these analog sensors emits a special event called "data" which occurs every time new data comes in from the sensor. Using this event, you can rewrite the first program you worked on in this lesson so that it continually updates.

## Do This

1.  Create an event to continuously check the `soundSensor`
    -   Drag out an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][0] to check the `soundSensor` for a `data` event
    -   ::: details [**Show Me How**]
        [][1]
        :::
2.  Inside the event, update the screen to display the value of the sound sensor
    -   Use the [`setText()`(#fff176)][2] and [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)][3] blocks to update the screen

**Run Your Code!** You should see the screen update in real-time based on the volume in the room. How low can you make the sensor go? How high can you make it go?

# Set Scale

The sound and light sensors range from 0-1023, but you can also use a [`setScale()`(#f78183)][0] block to adjust the range of the sensors. These blocks are usually added to the beginning of your code and only need to be used once.

# Do This

1.  Set the range of the `soundSensor` to be between 0 and 100
    -   Add a [`soundSensor.setScale()`(#f78183)][1] block to the top of your code.
    -   Set the first parameter to `0` and the second parameter to `100`. This represents a range from 0-100
    -   ::: details [Show Me How]
        [][2]
        :::

**Run Your Code!** You should notice the values now stay between 0 and 100 no matter how loud it is near the sound sensor.

# Change Event

The `data` event is fine if you don't mind your code running constantly, but sometimes that's not the most efficient solution to your problem. The sensor `change` event only fires if the sensor value has changed since the last reading, which can make sure your program isn't running code when it's not necessary.

Let's write a program that buzzes and updates the screen anytime the temperature sensor changes.

## Do This

1.  Create an event to check the `tempSensor` when it changes
    -   Drag out an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][0] to check the `tempSensor` for a `change` event
    -   ::: details [**Show Me How**]
        [][1]
        :::
2.  Play a sound and update the screen when the temperature changes
    -   Inside the [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][2] block:
        -   Have the buzzer make a sound.
        -   Update the screen with the new temperature value

**Run Your Code!** Try placing your thumb over the temperature sensor to warm up the sensor and get it to change. See how your program responds!

<hr />

-   (Optional): Change the event type to "data" and run the program to see what happens. Don't run the program for very long though - you'll hurt your ears!
-   ::: details [**Whoa! What Happened?**]
    The `data` event happens continuously, which means the code inside it is always happening. This is why you constantly hear the buzzer even when the temperature hasn't changed!

    When you use the `change` event, the event only happens when a _change_ occurs, which is much less frequent. This is why you only hear the buzzer when the temperature changes

    Sometimes you can't notice the difference between a "change" and "data" event, and sometimes it makes a **BIG** difference!
    :::

CSD U6 - Sensors - PA_2222.bubble_choice_description: Use the temperature sensor to create a thermometer app
CSD U6 - Sensors - PA_2222.long_instructions:
# Make a Thermometer App

While the light and sound sensors have just a raw value with the `value` property, the temperature sensor is a little bit smarter. Instead of `tempSensor.value`, there are two properties [`tempSensor.F`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/tempSensor.F/) and [`tempSensor.C`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/tempSensor.C/) which convert the raw input value to either Fahrenheit or Celsius.

Let's use these blocks to display the temperature near the circuit playground like a thermostat does.

## Do This

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [Create an event to continuously check the `tempSensor`]
	- Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the `tempSensor` has `data`
    :::
2) ::: details [Update the screen to display the temperature in F and C]
	- Inside the [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/):
		- Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the Fahrenheit label to [`tempSensor.F`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/tempSensor.F/)
    	- Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the Celsius label to [`tempSensor.C`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/tempSensor.C/)
    :::

**Run your program!** You should see the temperature update in real-time. To test the program, hold your finger over the sensor and see if the temperature increases due to body heat.

start_html.Current Temperature in Fahrenheit and Ce: Current Temperature in Fahrenheit and Celsius

CSD U6 - Sensors - PB_2222.long_instructions:
# Interactive Birthday Card

This app simulates an interactive greeting card that you can find in stores. The app displays several candles and, when the user blows on the circuit playground, the candles should disappear and the app should say "Happy Birthday!". This app will need to use the `tempSensor` event to detect a `change` in the temperature.

## Do This

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [Create an event to check when the `tempSensor` has changed]
	- Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the `tempSensor` has a `change`
    :::
2) ::: details [When the temperature changes, update the card to hide the candles, say "Happy Birthday", and buzz]
	- Inside the [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/):
    	- Use [`hideElement()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/hideElement/) to hide the candles
        - Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the text of the `titleLabel` element to "Happy Birthday!"
        - Use [`buzzer.frequency()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/buzzer.frequency/) to make the card make a noise
   :::

**Run Your App!** You should be able to blow on the Circuit Playground to trigger the temperature sensor. This will make the candles disappear and the circuit playground will buzz to wish you Happy Birthday!

start_html.Blow On The Circuit Playground to Blow O: Blow On The Circuit Playground to Blow Out the Candles!

CSD U6 - Sensors - PC_2222.bubble_choice_description: Use the light sensor and buzzer to create sci-fi noises and simulate a theremin
CSD U6 - Sensors - PC_2222.long_instructions:
# Light Theremin

A Theremin is a musical instrument that creates tones based on how it reacts to the environment. Most spooky otherworldly music is made from Theremin sounds.

Your app will create spooky sounds by reacting to light. When there is low light, the theremin should make low tones. When there is a lot of light, it should make high tones. But, just so it’s not totally annoying, it should only make noises when turned on using a dropdown on the screen.

[Click here to see a video of the finished app](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1LlHFrxrXtQim3CJ7tKGA8N90hMQefklQ/view?usp=sharing)

## Do This

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [Create an event to continuously check the `lightSensor`]
	- Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the `lightSensor` has `data`
    :::
2) ::: details [Get the value from the dropdown and store it in a variable]
	- Use a [`var x = __`(#BB77C7)](/docs/applab/declareAssign_x/) and [`getProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/getProperty/) block to get the value from the dropdown
    :::
3) ::: details [If the value is `"on"`: play the buzzer using the light sensor's value]
	- Add an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the value of the dropdown variable
    - Use the [`buzzer.frequency()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/buzzer.frequency/) and [`lightSensor.value`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/lightSensor.value/) blocks to play frequencies that match the light sensor
    :::
4) ::: details [If the value is `"off"`: stop the buzzer]
	- Add an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the value of the dropdown variable
    - Use the [`buzzer.stop()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/buzzer.stop/) block to stop the buzzer
    :::

**Run Your App!** When you change the dropdown to "on", the circuit playground should start buzzing. Shining a flashlight on the circuit playground should create a high-pitched buzz, and keeping the circuit playground in the dark should create a low-pitched buzz.

CSD U6 - Sensors - CA_2222.bubble_choice_description: Learn to use the threshold block with the sound sensor
CSD U6 - Sensors - CA_2222.long_instructions:
# Change Threshold

By default a sensor's `change` event fires every time the sensor value changes at all, even by one. The light and sound sensors are constantly fluctuating, so you probably want the `change` event to be a little less responsive. 

The [`threshold`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/lightSensor.threshold/) property allows you to set how much a sensor should change before considering it a `change` event. For example, setting `soundSensor.threshold = 100` would cause the sound sensor's `change` event only to trigger if its value increased or decreased by at least 100.

## Do This

This app changes the background color of the screen whenever the sound sensor value changes, but we want to only respond to big changes in volume (like a loud noise). Use the [`soundSensor.threshold`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.threshold/) block to fix it.

1) Add a [`soundSensor.threshold`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.threshold/) block before the event handler
2) Test out how different threshold values impact the "change" event
3) Choose a threshold value that makes the screen background change only when a loud noise is sensed.

_Tip: Your threshold depends on how much ambient noise there is in the room, and how much it changes. A threshold that works in a quiet room may not work in a louder classroom._

CSD U6 - Sensors - CB_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app where the background color reacts to the light, sound, and temperature sensors
CSD U6 - Sensors - CB_2222.long_instructions:
# Changing Colors with Sensors

The [`setScale()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.setScale/) block can convert the full range of sensor readings (0-1023) into different ranges, including ranges that can be used for RGB values (0-255). Let's build on that idea to make an app that can changes the background color based on the three sensors.

The app has already been started for you and works correctly for the light sensor - if you run the program, the background color will change based on the light sensor's value. Your task is to finish the program so the background color is also affected by the sound and temperature sensors.

# Do This

**Planning:**
- Look at the code below in order to understand how the light sensor is affecting the background color.

**In Code Mode:**
1) Set the `soundSensor` scale to a range of values between 0 and 255
2) Create a variable for the `soundSensor` value
3) Create a variable for the `tempSensor` value
	- You can use either [`tempSensor.F`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/tempSensor.F/) or [`tempSensor.C`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/tempSensor.C/) for the temperature values
4) Update the background color of the screen
	- Use a [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) block and your sensor variables instead of the `255` values

**Run Your Code!** You should be able to change the background color by changing the temperature, light, or sound near the circuit playground!

CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalC_2222.bubble_choice_description: Use the sound sensor to create an interactive volume meter that warns the user if the volume gets too loud
CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
![expandable](https://images.code.org/e89a6d307b6bcda311a64d3d530ef280-image-1648853925073.gif)
Click to Expand
# Volume Meter Version 2 This app is the same as the "Volume Meter" practice level, which displays how loud or quiet your environment is. It uses a button that changes height to react to the sound in the room - the louder the sound, the taller the button. However, this version of the app should also react to how loud or quiet the room is. The button itself and the background should also react based on the volume in the room - if it is too loud, the app gives a warning by changing colors. ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [Set the `soundSensor` scale to match the height of the app screen] - Add a [`soundSensor.setScale()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.setScale/) block to set the range of values from 30-400 ::: 2) ::: details [Create an event to continuously check the `soundSensor`] - Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the `soundSensor` has `data` ::: 3) ::: details [Update the button's height to match the `soundSensor` value] - Use the [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) and [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.value/) blocks to update the `height` of the button ::: 4) ::: details [If the room is too loud: make the volume button red and the screen background black] - Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to detect if the [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.value/) is greater than 200. - Update the color of the volume button to red - Update the background color of the screen to black ::: 5) ::: details [If the room is a normal volume: make the volume button blue and the screen background white] - Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to detect if the [`soundSensor.value`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/soundSensor.value/) is less than 200. - Update the color of the volume button to blue - Update the background color of the screen to white ::: **Run The App!** As you speak or make noise near the circuit playground, the app should react in real time!

CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalE_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that simulates a device that automatically opens and closes window blinds based on the sunlight outside.
CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalE_2222.long_instructions:
# Automatic Windows

Create an app prototype that simulates a device that automatically opens and closes window blinds based on the sunlight outside. The app should use the light sensor to detect the light level in the room: if there is a lot of light, open the blinds to let in the sunlight through the window. If there is not a lot of light, close the blinds to turn on other lights inside the house.

This app simulates this effect by using images on the app screen. This app has an image element named `blindsImage` that displays window blinds. If we want to open the window, we need to hide the `blindsImage` element; if we want to close the window, we need to show the `blindsImage` element.

## Do This
1) Use a `setScale` block to set the scale of the lightSensor from 0-100
2) Use an `onBoardEvent` to detect the data from the lightSensor
3) If the lightSensor value is greater than 50: hide the `blindsImage` element, which simulates opening the window
4) If the lightSensor value is less than 50: show the `blindsImage` element, which simulates closing the window

CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalD_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that could be used in an environmental or ecology setting to monitor plants or animals in an environment
CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalD_2222.long_instructions:
# Environmental App

Create an app prototype that could be used in an environmental or ecology setting to monitor plants or animals in an environment. For example, the circuit playground could be placed in a pet sleeping area and if the app detects the temperature is too cold, it could recommend the heat be turned on. Or, the circuit playground could be placed with a plant and if the app detects that the light is too low, it could recommend that the plant be moved into the sunlight.

You may not be able to create the "perfect" app yet, but you can develop a **prototype** which shows the general idea of the app and some of the basic features behind how it could work.

CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalG_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that could be used in a safety setting to warn the user of an unsafe environment
CSD U6 - Sensors - ChalG_2222.long_instructions:
# Safety App

Create an app prototype that could be used to detect safety concerns and react or alert the user. For example, it could detect when the temperature is too hot, possibly indicating that there is a fire. Or the app could detect when the noise level is too loud and could hurt someone's ear drums, then give the user a warning. 

You may not be able to create the "perfect" app yet, but you can develop a **prototype** which shows the general idea of the app and some of the basic features behind how it could work.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.teacher_markdown: The accelerometer has two properties: the `roll` and `pitch`. The `roll` corresponds to tilting left and right, and `pitch` corresponds to tilting forwards and backwards. Students should notice this if they're holding their circuit playground level to the ground with the USB cable pointing away from them so all the lettering appears correctly. Students may also experiment with moving their circuit playground in the physical space - moving it up and down or left and right - but this doesn't affect the accelerometer. Only rotating and tilting the circuit playground will change the roll and pitch.

# Roll

This program should display "Left" or "Right" on the screen, depending on which way the board is tilted.

## Do This

1.  Get the `roll` property of the accelerometer and store it in a variable
    -   Use the [`var x = __;`(#BB77C7)][0] and [`accelerometer.getOrientation()`(#f78183)][1] blocks to get the `roll` value
2.  If the board is tilted left: update the screen to say "Left"
    -   Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)][2] and `<`(#FFB74D) or `>`(#FFB74D) blocks to determine if the board is tilted left
    -   Use a [`setText()`(#fff176)][3] block to update the label on the screen
3.  If the board is tilted right: update the screen to say "Right"
    -   Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)][4] and `<`(#FFB74D) or `>`(#FFB74D) blocks to determine if the board is tilted left
    -   Use a [`setText()`(#fff176)][5] block to update the label on the screen

**Run Your Code!** As you tilt the board left and right, you should see the screen update

# Combining the Accelerometer and Counter Pattern

You can use the accelerometer with variables and the [counter pattern][0] to move elements on the screen depending on how the circuit playground is tilted.

In this app the goalie is trying to block the soccer ball. The ball will move automatically across the screen using the counter pattern and the player should move when you tilt the board, but the code isn't finished.

## Do This

1.  Find the section of the code that says "Add your code here!"
2.  Use a [`getProperty()`(#fff176)][1] block to get the `y` position from the `player` element ([**Show Me Where**][2])
3.  Use the [`accelerometer.getOrientation()`(#f78183)][3] block to get the `pitch` property from the accelerometer ([**Show Me Where**][4])
4.  Add these two variables together to update the player's y-position ([**Show Me Where**][5])
    -   You can use a `+`(#FFB74D) block, or you can type in the two variables in the empty box in the block

**Run Your Program!** You should be able to tilt the Circuit Playground to move the player on the screen!

Right now, only one star moves around and only once when the app first loads. We need to add an event to detect when the board shakes, and then update the app so _all_ of the stars move on the screen ## Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [Create an event to check when the circuit playground shakes] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect when the `accelerometer` has a `shake` event ::: 2) ::: details [Move each star to a random location] - Use [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) and [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/applab/randomNumber_min_max/) blocks to update the `x` and `y` property of each star - You will need ten [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) blocks in total - two blocks for each `x` and `y`, repeated for all five stars. - You can use the `star1` code as an example for how the other stars should look ::: **Run Your Code!** You should be able to shake the circuit playground and see the stars move around!

CSD U6 - Accelerometer - PF_2222.bubble_choice_description: Tilt the circuit playground to get as close as you can to a target number
CSD U6 - Accelerometer - PF_2222.long_instructions:
# Number Tilting Game

This app simulates a game where you try to match a number with a randomly generated target number. You can tilt the circuit playground left and right to adjust your number, trying to get it as close to the target number as possible. Once it's close enough, pressing the right button on the circuit playground will lock in your number.

The game has already been started, but the code that updates your number based on the circuit playground is missing. We'll need to use variables and the Counter Pattern to update our number and update the screen

## Do This

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [Detect when the circuit playground tilts left or right and store it in a variable]
	- Use the [`var x = __;`(#BB77C7)](/docs/applab/declareAssign_x/) and [`accelerometer.getOrientation()`(#f78183) blocks with either `pitch` or `roll` to get the tilt value of the circuit playground
    :::
2) ::: details [Update the value of your number using the circuit playground tilt value]
	- Use the Counter Pattern to add the circuit playground tilt value to the `yourNumber` variable
    :::
3) ::: details [Update the screen with the new number]
	- Use [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) to update the `yourNumberLabel`
    :::

**Run Your Code!** You should be able to tilt the circuit playground left and right and see your number update on the screen. Once it's close to the target number, press the right circuit playground button and see how close you were!

CSD U6 - Accelerometer - PG_2222.bubble_choice_description: Tilt the Circuit Playground to select one of four possible animals
CSD U6 - Accelerometer - PG_2222.long_instructions:
# Four Corners

This app lets you use the circuit playground to move a cursor to four quadrants on the screen with different animals in them. This is similar to children's games that use a controller to select their favorite animal. This requires using [`if statements`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to update the position of the cursor based on the tilt of the circuit playground.

## Do This

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [Get the `pitch` and `roll` properties of the accelerometer and store them in two variables]
	- Use two [`variable`(#BB77C7)](/docs/applab/declareAssign_x/) blocks to determine the `pitch` and `roll` of the circuit playground
    :::
2) Use [`if statements`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to update the cursor position based on the `pitch` and `roll` values
	- If the `roll` is `<`(#FFB74D) -20: move the cursor to the left side of the screen by updating the `x` position to `50`
    - If the `roll` is `>`(#FFB74D) 20: move the cursor to the right side of the screen by updating the `x` position to `280`
    - If the `pitch` is `<`(#FFB74D) -20: move the cursor to the top of the screen by updating the `y` position to `50`
    - If the `pitch` is `>`(#FFB74D) 20: move the cursor to the bottom of the screen by updating the `y` position to `400`

**Run Your Code!** You should be able to tilt the circuit playground and have the cursor jump to one of four quadrants

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Assistive Mouse

Assistive Technology helps people with disabilities use technology in the same way able-bodied individuals can. For example, someone with a physical disability with their hand or wrist may not be able to use a mouse the same way we can. But, the circuit playground can help then navigate an app in a different way.

This app is designed to use the accelerometer to move the cursor, then use the sound-sensor to detect when the user says “Click”. The sound sensor has already been coded, but the app still needs the accelerometer.

## Do This

1.  Create an event to continuously check the accelerometer
2.  Get the `pitch` and `roll` properties of the accelerometer and store them in two variables
3.  Update the `x` and `y` position of the cursor based on the `pitch` and `roll`
