CSD U6 - Accelerometer - ChalA_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app that uses the accelerometer to simulate a safety sensor on construction equipment
CSD U6 - Accelerometer - ChalA_2222.long_instructions:
# Safety Settings

Many construction tools or equipment have safety sensors built-in to the devices so they can only be operated under certain conditions. This helps avoid situations where someone injures themselves by accidentally using the device without taking the proper safety precautions.

Create an app that simulates firing a laser (aka: the colorLEDs) by pressing a button, but will only work when the device is pointed away from the user so the laser doesn't go into their eyes. This requires using the Accelerometer and detecting the `roll` or `pitch` of the device.

The app has already been started for you so that the screen will display the roll and pitch of the circuit playground. Your task is to determine the roll or pitch when the circuit playground is facing away from you, then add code so the colorLEDs only turn on when the circuit playground is in the correct position.

## Do This
**Planning:**
- Run the app and rotate the Circuit Playground to determine the correct `roll` or `pitch` values that represent when the circuit playground is facing away from you

**In Code Mode:**

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) Create an event to check when the left button is pressed
2) ::: details [If the circuit playground is facing away from the user: turn on all of the LEDs]
	- Use an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the value of the `roll` or `pitch` that represents when it is turned away from the user
	- Inside the [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/): turn on all of the LEDs, which represents firing the laser
   :::

**Run Your Code!** If you press the button while the circuit playground is flat on the table, nothing should happen. But if you hold the circuit playground so it is facing away from you, the lights should turn on.

CSD U6 - Accelerometer - ChalC_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app that simulates the sensor in cars and trucks that detects if the wheels are aligned and warns about flat tires
CSD U6 - Accelerometer - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
# Car Wheel Alignment

Most cars have sensors to detect if the car is level, and will create a warning message if the car detects it is tilted slightly to the right or left. This can indicate a flat tire or that the wheels are out of alignment and the car needs to be taken to a service center.

Create an app that simulates this sensor, using the circuit playground to detect if it is level or tilted slightly to the left or right.
- If the circuit playground is level, the status message should say "Wheels are Aligned"
- If the circuit playground is tilted to the left, the status message should say "Check left side tires"
- If the circuit playground is tilted to the right, the status message should say "Check right side tires"

## Do This
1) Create an event to continuously check the accelerometer
2) Get the `roll` property of the accelerometer and store it in a variable
3) If the circuit playground is tilted to the left: display "Check left side tires" on the screen
4) If the circuit playground is tilted to the right: display "Check right side tires" on the screen

**Run Your App!** If the circuit playground is on a level surface, the app should say "Wheels are Aligned". If you put the circuit playground on a tilted surface, the app should update to a different status message

**Optional Extensions:**
- Change the color of the text to make it appear like an error message if the circuit playground is tilted
- Add a buzzer notification if the circuit playground detects it's tilted

CSD U6 - Accelerometer - ChalG_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app prototype that could be used in an accessibility setting to make it easier for someone with a disability to use technology
CSD U6 - Accelerometer - ChalG_2222.long_instructions:
# Accessibility App

Create an app prototype that could be used to increase accessibility and access to technology for people with disabilities. For example, a non-verbal user could use the accelerometer and LEDs or buzzer to communicate. Or the circuit playground could buzz anytime the mouse moves over certain UI elements to let a person with a visual impairment know they can interact with that part of the app. For more ideas around accessibility and computing, you can visit the [Access CSforAll website](https://www.washington.edu/accesscomputing/accesscsforall/videos) for more ideas.

You may not be able to create the "perfect" app yet, but you can develop a **prototype** which shows the general idea of the app and some of the basic features behind how it could work.

Students will have a tough time predicting their results here, but that's okay - it's more important that they realize that there should be matching sounds between the left buttons and the right buttons. When students run the code, they can press the buttons multiple times to try and find the matching pairs. They should discover the following pairs create the same sounds:

-   261 \<> C4
-   329 \<> E4
-   493 \<> B4
-   392 \<> G4

As students will discover soon, these frequencies correspond to musical notes like they might see on a piano. For now, they should leave this level understanding that certain frequencies correspond to certain "notes".

contained levels.long_instructions:
# Frequencies and Notes

The buttons on the left will make the circuit playground buzz using the `frequency` block. The buttons on the right will make the circuit playground buzz using a new `note` block.

Read through the code and predict if you think any of the buttons will create the same sound. Your answer will be a pair - for example, "392" and "E4".

After making your prediction, run the app and see if you were right. Try to see if any buttons on the left make the same sound as buttons on the right.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Frequency and Music

Using carefully-chosen frequencies, we can use the [`buzzer.frequency()`(#f78183)][0] block to create a musical instrument like a piano.

In this app, when you play the piano, the note and the frequency will appear. Using these frequencies in your code will let you simulate musical instruments and play songs

# New Block: Note

Instead of remembering each frequency, you can also use the new [`buzzer.note()`(#f78183)][1] block to play a specific note. For example, playing a "C" Note on the piano for one second can be coded using:

[`buzzer.note("C4", 1000)`(#f78183)][2]

The "4" indicates which octave the note is in - "C5" and "C6" would be higher versions of the same note, and "C3" and "C2" would be lower versions.

# Do this

-   Try to play a song on the piano! Click below to see some examples

::: details [Mary had a Little Lamb]
E - D - C - D - E - E - E

D - D - D

E - E - E

E - D - C - D - E - E - E

E - D - D - E - D - C
:::

::: details [Twinkle Twinkle Little Star]

# Piano Notes

This is the same piano from the last level, but there are some bugs!

## Do This

1.  Edit the code so that all keys are using a [`buzzer.note()`(#f78183)][0] block to play the corresponding note.
2.  Make sure that all the values passed in to [`buzzer.note()`(#f78183)][1] are notes, and not frequencies.
    -   _Hint: Remember to put quotes around the notes! e.g [`buzzer.note("A4", 100)`(#f78183)][2]_

Note: This level starts in text mode because of some of the bugs! As you debug, you can check your work by trying to convert back to block mode and see if it works correctly.

# Notes and Octaves

You can play the same note at different octaves, such as a "low note" or "high note". You can represent this in your code by adding a number at the end of a note. For example:

-   [`buzzer.note("C1", 100)`(#f78183)][0] would play a C note at the lowest octave
-   [`buzzer.note("C8", 100)`(#f78183)][1] would play a C note at the highest octave
-   [`buzzer.note("C", 100)`(#f78183)][2] would play a C note at the default octave, "C4"

## Do This

1.  Complete the app below by filling in the missing notes with the correct octave

**Run Your Code!** Click each button to listen to the notes. Notice that at very low and very high octaves, the sound becomes distorted and unrecognizable

This app will let the user play a song by clicking the buttons from top-to-bottom.

The code uses a new block called an `array` to keep the notes of the song in order.

## Do This

-   What parts of the code look similar to the [`colorLeds`(#f78183)][0] blocks?
-   What parts of the code look different from the [`colorLeds`(#f78183)][1] blocks?

**Run the code** to see how the program behaves.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
## Questions to Consider

-   When might an array be more useful than a variable?
-   Why do you always need to assign an array to a variable?
-   How can you access the elements in your array?
https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.teacher_markdown:
## Discussion Goals

This is the first introduction to arrays, and students will have an opportunity to try them out in the lesson, so understanding why arrays are helpful and the general ways that can use them is more important than the particular syntax or commands in the video.  Students should understand that arrays are intended to hold several pieces of information, usually all of the same type.  Just like any other piece of information, it needs to be assigned to a variable for a programmer to find it again.  Programmers can access each element of the array by its **index**, or its position number in the array.  Students will have a chance to practice the exact syntax in the lesson.

# playNotes

This app uses the [`buzzer.playNotes()`(#f78183)][0] block to play a sequence of notes in a row like a song. It uses an **array** to tell which notes to play. A few important things to notice are:

-   The array uses `null` to represent a "rest" in the music, which is a short pause
-   The number at the very end is the **tempo** - it determines how long each note lasts.
    -   _higher_ numbers mean the notes play _faster_, so the song has a _fast tempo_
    -   _lower_ numbers mean the notes play _slower_, so the song has a _slow tempo_

## Do This

1.  Run the app to see how it works
2.  Reset the app and change the temp so the song plays twice as fast
    -   Note: if we want the song to play _faster_, does that mean we want a _bigger number_ or _smaller number_?

# Doorbell

This app simulates a doorbell. When the user presses the button, a scale of notes should play (C, D, E, F, G, A, B, C) to let them know someone is at the door.

## Do This

1.  When the doorbell button is pressed, play the notes on a scale
    -   In the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0], add a [`buzzer.playNotes()`(#f78183)][1] block
    -   Replace the default notes with a scale of the natural notes: `"C4", "D4", "E4", "F4", "G4", "A4", "B4", "C5"`
    -   If necessary, use the ⬅️ icon to remove extra spaces in the array

**Run the app!** When you press the button, the circuit playground should play a song!

(Optional) Add more elements to your array so that the scale also plays in reverse. This means the doorbell would sound like someone playing the piano going up the keys and then going back down to the starting point.

# Musical Emojis

Karla is making an app for young children that helps students identify emotions with images and sounds. Users can click buttons for different emotions and images will appear and music will play that represent that emotion. Karla hopes to eventually turn this into a childrens book where each time someone turns the page, a new song will play to match the emotion on that page.

Karla has already designed the app and added code to make the emojis change, but needs help adding music to her app.

## Do This

-   Add code so a "happy" song plays when the happy button is clicked [(Show Me Where)][0]. Your song should include at least four notes and at least one rest.
-   Add code so a "sad" song plays when the sad button is clicked [(Show Me Where)][1]. Your song should include at least four notes and at least one rest.

_Note: Creating "happy" and "sad" songs is a creative process and there's no single right answer. You can design a simple song that you think sounds happy or sad, or you can try looking up the notes to a song you like and playing part of it. Either way, make sure you have at least four notes and at least one rest for each song_

CSD U6 - Music - ChalB_2222.long_instructions: # playSong Block Songs are a combination of different notes and different tempos, such as quarter-notes or half-notes. For example, the beginning of "Happy Birthday To You!" contains two eighth notes, three quarter notes, and a half notes. Each of these types of notes are played at different speeds. The `playSong` block lets you play music like this, where different notes play at different speeds. The block uses an _array_ to represent each note: ![](https://images.code.org/928fef949ba51d63bf3cd80b75420b55-image-1646863976712.png) And then **another aray** is used to represent the frequency and duration of each note: ![](https://images.code.org/27a8bfec1068081d590054d02a096005-image-1646864149162.png) The code above would play a "C" quarter-note, a "D" half-note, and an "E" whole-note. ## Do This 1) Run the code below and click the "Happy Birthday" button. The circuit playground should play the first part of the song 2) Using the code as an example, create your own song that plays when you press the second button. You may want to look up sheet music online for inspiration. - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ![](https://images.code.org/e39067402845d1eb39fc4da7a914433e-image-1646864551184.gif) :::

# Build-A-Song

This app introduces a new block, [`appendItem()`(#BB77C7)](/docs/applab/appendItem/), which can be used to add elements to an array. Using this block, we can add new notes to an array to let the user build their own song. Each time the user clicks on a button, we'll add the note to an array called `song`. Then, when the user clicks the Start button, it will play all of the notes stored in the `song` array.

The app has already been started for you, with the "C" button using the [`appendItem()`(#BB77C7)](/docs/applab/appendItem/) block to add a new note to our song. Using this as an example, finish the app so the user can build their own song by clicking each of the buttons.

## Do This

1) Using the "C" button as an example, add code to each of the other buttons to append a new note to the `song` array

**Run Your App!** You should be able to click each note button, then play the song you created!

They may notice that `updateScreen()` appears in three places: within the two button events, and as a larger green block at the bottom of the code. It's okay if they're not completely sure how the green block is working, and they may try to describe what's happening by relating to variables - that a variable can be used in place of a value, and maybe `updateScreen()` is being used as a placeholder for the code at the bottom of the screen. Guide students to notice this is useful because the same code can be used in two different places (the left button and the right button).

It's okay to not come to a firm conclusion, since students will watch a video in the next level that explains Functions and how to use them in code.

This app lets you click on aliens on the screen and the LEDs will light up to match the color of the aliens. The app only has two colors for each alien: yellow or green.

The app has already been started for you and has already **defined** two functions: `greenLEDs` and `yellowLEDs` [**(Show Me Where)**][0]

You still need to **call** these functions within your program. Two of the aliens are already working correctly. Your task is to make the other aliens work correctly too!

## Do This:

1.  Look at the two examples that have already been completed [**(Show Me Where)**][1]
2.  When you click an alien, change the LEDs to the color of that alien
    -   Inside each [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][2], drag out a green [`myFunction()`(#68D995)][3] block.
    -   Replace `myFunction` with either `greenLEDs` or `yellowLEDs` to match the alien you click

# Creating Functions

In this app, some new aliens have appeared that are red and blue! When the user clicks on an alien, the LEDs should turn on to match the alien.

The red aliens have already been completed, but the blue aliens still need to be finished. You'll need to **define** a function called `blueLEDs`, then **call** the function inside each event.

## Do This

**1) Defining Our Function**:

-   At the bottom of the code, add a new [`function myFunction() {}`(#68D995)][0] block [**(Show Me Where)**][1].
-   Name the function `blueLEDs`. Add several [`color()`(#f78183)][2] blocks to make every LED blue

**2) Calling Our Function**:

-   At the top of the code, find the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][3] blocks for the two blue aliens [**(Show Me Where)**][4].
-   Add a [`myFunction()`(#68D995)][5] block to each event. Change the function mame to `blueLEDs`.

**Run your code!** When you click an alien, the lights on the LED should light up to match

# Using Functions for Repeated Code This app has the same aliens from before, but they are easily frightened - any loud noises or bright lights will make the aliens jump around on the screen. In the code, this is accomplished with two [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][0] blocks. When we look at those two blocks, a lot of the code is repeated in both places. This is really inefficient! It would be much clearer if all of this code was **defined** in its own function in one place, and then we **call** that function every place we want to use it. This makes our code shorter and easier to read. ## Do This
[expandable][1]
Click to Expand
**1) Defining Your Functions** - At the bottom of the code, **define** a new function called `moveAliens` [(**Show Me Where**)][2] - Find the sections of the code that is repeated in multiple places. Move that code into the function you just created **2) Calling Your Functions** - Replace the original code by **calling** the `moveAliens` function **Check Yourself:** By now, your code should be _shorter_ and still work the same as before. You can run your code and make sure the aliens scatter when a bright light or loud sound is made.

# Adding New Features! One advantage to using functions is it's easy to add new features! Let's add a new feature that lets you shake the circuit playground and causes the aliens to scatter.
[expandable][0]
Click to Expand
## Do This 1. Add a new [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][1] that uses the `accelerometer` to detect a `shake` event. 2. Drag out a green [`myFunction()`(#68D995)][2] block to **call** the `moveAliens` function **Run Your Code!** By making these two small changes, you should be able to shake the circuit playground and have the aliens move around the screen!

Students should notice that the left and right buttons are used, and that the function at the bottom is using the accelerometer to move something on the screen. Students may predict that the function changes depending on which button is pressed - the left button moves the purple bug, and the right button moves the orange bug. Students may also notice that the function has a variable, `bug`, that is included at the top of the function and used throughout. 

In the next level, students will watch a video describing how these functions work and how `bug` is a **parameter** that can be used to change the behavior of a function when the function is called, like moving the orange bug or purple bug.

-   How do parameters make functions more useful?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.teacher_markdown:
## Discussion Goals

Students will have a chance to practice defining functions with parameters in the lesson, so it's not necessary for them to understand the exact process. Students should understand that parameters are useful because they let programmers use the same function to solve problems that are very similar, but with slight differences.  If multiple functions are almost alike, but have a small difference, students may want to combine those functions into one, and use a parameter to account for the difference.

# Functions with Parameters

This app has a new set of aliens with all new colors. We can use a function with **parameters** to make it easier to change colors. 

The `colorLEDs` function has already been defined with a **parameter** called `color`. One alien has already been setup - it calls `colorLEDs("cyan")` to turn all the LEDs cyan to match the alien. We need to make the other aliens work too!

## Do This

1.  Inside each [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0]: drag out a [`myFunction(n)`(#68D995)][1] block
2.  Replace the function name with `colorLEDs`
3.  Replace the **parameter** with the color you want to change to. For example: `"orange"`, `"purple"`, etc.
    -   You can try any of the colors listed on this [Color Name website][2].

**Run Your Code!** Verify that the LEDs change colors to match the alien!

# Defining Functions with Parameters In this app, the aliens are hungry and have a choice of foods we can offer them. Clicking on a food should replace _each_ of the empty plates with that food. Each empty plate is represented by three different image elements - `food1`, `food2`, and `food3`. We'll create a **function** that updates all of the foods with the same image, and that image changes depending on which food you click. This will be the **parameter** in the function. ## Do This: **1) Define Your Function** - At the bottom of the code, drag out a [`function myFunction(n) {}`(#68D995)][0] block ([**Show Me Where**][1]) - Rename the function to `setFoods`. Change the parameter to `food`
**2) Update the Foods** - Inside the function: use three [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][2] blocks to update the `image` property of the `food1`, `food2`, and `food3` elements - In each [`setProperty()`(#fff176)][3] block, replace the `image` value with the parameter `food`
**3) Call Your Function** - Inside each [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][4] for the food buttons: drag out a [`myFunction(n)`(#68D995)][5] block. Replace the function name with `setFoods` - Update the **parameter** with the image that corresponds to each food: - Birthday Cake: `"image://BirthdayCake.png"` - Pizza Slice: `"image://PizzaSlice.png"` - Ramen: `"image://Ramen.png"` - Taco: `"image://Taco.png"`

# Light Patterns

This app creates a light pattern when the button is clicked. Right now, the pattern always uses the same colors - red and blue. Let's update the app so it can use any two colors by creating a function with two parameters.

## Do This

_Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_

1) ::: details [Update the function definition to use two parameters]
	- Find the `twoColors()` function and press the `→`(#68D995) arrow twice to add two parameters `color1` and `color2` ([**Show Me Where**](#triggercallout=todo1))
	- Update the code inside the function to use the parameters `color1` and `color2` instead of the colors `"red"` and `"blue"` every time ([**Show Me Where**](#triggercallout=todo2))
    :::
2) ::: details [Update the call to the function so it uses different color values]
	- Inside the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) block, press the `→`(#68D995) arrow twice to update the `twoColors()` function ([**Show Me Where**](#triggercallout=todo3)). Use any two colors you want!
    :::

**Run your code!** You should be able to see the pattern with your own two colors instead.

_Bonus_: Add another button that does the same pattern with two _different_ colors. You can add as many buttons as you want!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions: # Digital Snowglobe A snowglobe is a toy with lots of glitter and small specks of paper in a glass sphere. When you shake the sphere, it looks like snow is swirling in the globe. Eric is working on creating a digital snowglobe - when you shake the circuit playground, it simulates snow falling on a screen. He has 10 pieces of snow he wants to simulate, but he’s only coded five of them so far because the code is becoming too repetitive. He needs help using a function to simplify his code, and then he needs to use that function to finish his app. He’s already brainstormed an idea for how the finished app can look. ## Do This: - Create a function called `moveSnow` that uses two parameters for the element name and the amount to move - Look at the lines of code that are repeated to move each snow element. Copy that code into the new `moveSnow` function - Update the code in the `moveSnow` function to use your parameters - Hint: Look for places where the code is identical between each snow element, but with just a name or value changed. This is where you can use your parameters instead. - Remove the code inside the `onBoardEvent()` and replace it with calls to the new `moveSnow()` function. Be sure to include all 10 snow elements.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Add Sensors and Debugging

Add your events and sensors to your app. You can add some labels to your app in Design Mode to help debug your app and display the sensor values, but your final app doesn't need any design elements. Test your device and make sure the sensors are working properly and generating the correct data before adding more to your code.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Logic and Physical Materials

Add the core logic to your app, especially how your device reacts to sensor data. Also start attaching your board to the physical materials you created. Your device should start to "merge together" with the physical materials you curated, and you may need to make small adjustments so things fit. Use your project guide to help complete your device. Test your app several times to see that it behaves as expected.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Review Your Device

Take a moment to review your device. Double-check that it meets all the requirements in the rubric - [click here to see the rubric][0]. Make any changes or updates you think are necessary, or you may decide that the device is fine.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then the purple Submit button to submit your project. Once you submit it, you won't be able to edit it.

# Connecting to an LED In this lesson, we'll learn how to connect an LED to your circuit playground to light up ::: details [**Click Here to See an Example**] ::: You will need an LED and two wires. 1. Make sure your Circuit Playground is unplugged from the computer. This helps make sure there isn't any accidental electricity that can damage your board. 2. Attach a wire so one end is connected to the `A0` pad on the Circuit Playground, and the other end is connected to the positive end of an LED 3. Attach a wire so one end is connected to the `GND` pad on the Circuit Playground, and the other end is connected to the negative end of an LED ::: details [**How can you tell which end is positive and negative?**] A standard LED has two wires coming out of the top: a longer wire and a shorter wire. The longer wire is always **positive** and should be connected to a numbered pin on the circuit playground. The shorter wire is always **negative** and should be connected to a `GND` pad on the circuit playground. Some LEDs have the positive and negative sides labeled with a + and - ::: ## When You Are Finished Plug in your Circuit Playground to your computer and verify it is connected, then press 'Run' on the screen. The LED should light up. If something isn't working correctly, **Always unplug your circuit playground from your computer before changing any wires**. This helps avoid any accidental electrical damage to your board.

Make sure students always unplug their their board before changing wires - otherwise, electricity may still be flowing and can damage the circuit playground. This is a good time to emphasize this norm and remind students of safety precautions when working with the circuit playground and their materials.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions: # Programming External LEDs The code below shows how we can get an LED to light up. It uses two new commands: [`pinMode()`(#4dd0e1)][0] and [`digitalWrite()`(#4dd0e1)][1] - [`pinMode()`(#4dd0e1)][2] tells your Circuit Playground that you want to use one of the external pads for either input or output. "Pin" is the generic term for the pads on the circuit playground, and pins can look different on other devices. - [`digitalWrite()`(#4dd0e1)][3] tells your Circuit Playground to start or stop sending electricity to the device on that pin. 1 means "on", and 0 means "off" The code below is supposed to turn on the LED connected to your board, but right now your LED is connected to pin "A0". You’ll need to change how your board is connected before it will work. ## Do This 1. Unplug your Circuit Playground from the computer 2. Disconnect and re-connect your wires so they use pin "A4" to match the code above. 3. Plug your Circuit Playground back into the computer. You may need to run the Maker Setup again **Run your code!** See if the LED lights up. If it doesn't light up, press the Reset button then follow the steps above to try re-wiring your board.

In general, students should always reset the app and unplug from the computer before making any wiring changes. Otherwise, it could ruin the LED or ruin the board.

# Add Another LED You can use any of the numbered pads to add additional LEDs. Let's use pin `"A1"` to add another LED. # Do This
[expandable][0]
Click to Expand
**Wiring Your Device:** - Disconnect your Circuit Playground from the computer - Connect another LED to the circuit playground using two wires: - One wire goes from the `GND` pin to the negative (-) part of the LED - One wire goes from the `"A1"` pin to the positive (+) part of the LED - Plug your Circuit Playground back into the computer **Coding Your Device:** 1. Tell the board to use pin `"A1"` for output - Drag out a [`pinMode()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block. Set the pin to `"A1"` and the mode to `"output"` 2. Turn pin `"A1"` on - Drag out a [`digitalWrite()`(#4dd0e1)][2] block. Set the pin to `"A1"` and the value to 1 **Run your program!** If it worked, both LEDs should turn on. _Debugging Tip: LEDs only work if the electricity is flowing from positive to negative. If your LED doesn't light up, make sure that it's oriented the right way._
https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.teacher_markdown: **Why Are We Talking Pins?** You may notice that in the early levels of this lesson students are programming in a much different way than they have before, directly manipulating pins. The `digitalWrite()` and `pinMode()` commands are useful to get our wiring set up quickly, but are not the core concerns of this lesson. As soon as students are comfortable wiring LED circuits we will introduce techniques to control those LEDs with the higher level commands that have been used up to this point (like `led.on()` and `led.off()`).

# Using Variables with LEDs Rather than using [`pinMode()`(#4dd0e1)][0] and [`digitalWrite()`(#4dd0e1)][1] all the time, we can also use variables to keep track of our LEDs. This lets us create more useful and descriptive names, like `redLED` or `headlightLED`. This app works the same as the last level, but uses the new [`createLed()`(#4dd0e1)][2] block. The first LED for `"A4"` has been setup for you and uses the familiar [`led.on()`(#f78183)][3] block, but replaces `led` with the variable name. Using this as a reference, add code for the LED on pin `"A1"`. # Do This _Note: In order to create this app, you'll need to be in text mode_ **Preparation** - Keep your LEDs wired just as they were before - Make sure you're in text mode, not block mode.
[expandable][4]
Click to Expand
**In Code Mode** 1. Create a new variable `rightLED` attached to pin "A1" - Drag out a [`createLed()`(#4dd0e1)][5] block. - Replace `myLed` with the variable name `rightLED`, and replace `pin` with the pin `"A1"`. 2. Turn the `rightLED` on - Drag out a [`led.on()`(#f78183)][6] - Replace the text `led` with `rightLED`. **Run Your Code!** Both LEDs should light up, just like before!

# More LED Blocks

Now that we're using [`createLed()`(#4dd0e1)][0], we can also use some of the additional LED functions like `blink` or `pulse` or `toggle`.

This app is setup to just turn both LEDs on. Instead, let's edit the app so one LED blinks every 500ms and another LED pulses every 1000ms.

# Do This

_Note: In order to create this app, you'll need to be in text mode_

**Preparation:**

-   Keep your LEDs wired just as they were before
-   Make sure you're in text mode, not block mode.

**In Code Mode:**

1.  Make the `leftLED` blink every 500 milliseconds
    -   Replace the line `leftLED.on()` with `leftLED.blink(500)`
2.  Make the `rightLED` pulse every 1000 milliseconds
    -   Replace the line `rightLED.on()` with `rightLED.pulse(1000)`
3.  Check your code for any typos. Make sure there aren't any missing parentheses!

**Run Your Code!** One LED should blink while the other pulses!

# Controlling LEDs Create an app that uses the toggle switch to either turn on the 10 `colorLEDs` on the Circuit Playground, or turns on two external LEDs connected to pins `"A0"` or `"A6"`. _Note: You can start this app in block mode, but you will need to switch to text mode eventually to finish the app_ ## Do This **Wiring Your Device** 1) ::: details [Connect an LED to pin `"A0"` using two wires.] - One wire connects the `GND` pin to the negative (-) part of the LED - Another wire connects the `"A0"` pin to the positive (+) part of the LED ::: 2) ::: details [Connect an LED to pin `"A6"` using two wires.] - One wire connects the `GND` pin to the negative (-) part of the LED - Another wire connects the `"A6"` pin to the positive (+) part of the LED ::: **Coding Your Device** 1) ::: details [Create two LED variables on pins `"A0"` and `"A6"`] - Drag out two [`createLed()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/applab/createLed/) blocks - Set the pins to `"A0"` and `"A6"` ::: 2) ::: details [When the `toggleSwitch` is closed: turn on the `colorLEDs` and turn off the external LEDs] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect with the `toggleSwitch` is `closed` - Turn on all of the `colorLEDs` using ten [`on()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/on/) blocks - Drag out two [`led.off()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/led.off/) blocks - Use text mode to replace `led` with your two variable names ::: 3) ::: details [When the `toggleSwitch` is open: turn off the `colorLEDs` and turn on the external LEDs] - Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) block to detect with the `toggleSwitch` is `open` - Turn off all of the `colorLEDs` using ten [`off()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/off/) blocks - Drag out two [`led.on()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/led.on/) blocks - Use text mode to replace `led` with your two variable names :::

Use it to check if [`lightSensor.value`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/lightSensor.value/) `<`(#FFB74D) `200`. - Inside the [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/): - Drag out an [`led.on()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/led.on/) block - Use text mode to replace `led` with your variable name ::: 3) ::: details [If the room is bright: turn off the LED] - Drag out an [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) block. Use it to check if [`lightSensor.value`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/lightSensor.value/) `>`(#FFB74D) `200`. - Inside the [`if statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/): - Drag out an [`led.off()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/led.off/) block - Use text mode to replace `led` with your variable name ::: **Run your code!** If you cover the light sensor, the LED should light up. If you uncover the light sensor and put it in light, the LED should turn off

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Little Alien Friend

Rosie is designing a children's toy to look like an alien. it has a physical body that uses 2 LEDs as the eye, and you communicate with it via an app. Each button on the app causes the alien to respond in a different way:

-   Pressing “Wake Up” has the alien open their eyes
-   Pressing “Listen” has the alien blink slowly as it listens to a story
-   Pressing “Sleep” puts the alien to sleep and closes its eyes

## Do This

1.  Wire up two LEDs to pins `"A0"` and `"A6"`
2.  Create two LED variables on pins `"A0"` and `"A6"`
3.  Use an `on` block in the Wake Up event
4.  Use a `blink` block in the Listen event
5.  Use an `off` block in the Sleep event

# LED Candle Create a device prototype for an LED Candle. This requires creating a holder for your candle out of physical materials, and then putting an LED through the top to light up. For example, you could roll up paper or use a cardboard toilet paper roll as the base of the candle, then have the LED sticking through the top. This is a **prototype** for your device, which means it won't be perfect and will probably be a little messy. Instead, focus on demonstrating how all of the pieces would fit together to create your device. ## Do This **Materials:** 1) Create your candle holder using physical materials, such as paper or cardboard 2) Place your LED and wires so they are in the correct location in your device 3) Get your Circuit Playground ready **In Code Mode:** 1) Create an LED variable 2) Add code so when you press the left button: the external LED turns on 3) Add code so when you press the right button: the external LED turns off 4) Connect your wires to your circuit playground and test your code **Run Your Code!** You should be able to turn on and off your candle using the circuit playground.

For example: - A picture of a face, but the eyes are LEDs - A picture of the night sky, but some stars are LEDs - A picture of a car, but the headlights are LEDs This is a **prototype** for your device, which means it won't be perfect and will probably be a little messy. Instead, focus on demonstrating how all of the pieces would fit together to create your device. ## Do This: **Materials:** 1) Draw your picture on a sheet of paper 2) Decide where the LEDs will go 3) Cut holes in your drawing and place the LEDs underneath. Example Sign
# Do Not Disturb Sign Create a device prototype that creates a "Do Not Disturb" sign that uses an LED to indicate that the sign is on or off. This kind of device is used in a variety of situations such as: - When recording studios are "on the air" and need to indicate they are recording and no one should talk - When photographers are developing photos in dark rooms and need to indicate that no one should open the door - When doctors are with a patient and need to indicate that no one should disturb the conversation This is a **prototype** for your device, which means it won't be perfect and will probably be a little messy. Instead, focus on demonstrating how all of the pieces would fit together to create your device. ## Do This **Materials:** 1) Create your sign to represent "Do Not Disturb". You could write out the words in letters, or use a symbol or drawing. 2) Create a place for your LED to go on the sign. Usually the LED is towards the bottom of the sign so people can see it clearly 3) Place your LED and wires so they are in the correct location in your device 4) Position your sign so it is in a prominent place that people can see. This may mean hanging your sign on a wall or creating a little stand for your sign so people can see it as they approach you. 5) Get your Circuit Playground ready **In Code Mode:** 1) Create an LED variable 2) When the left button is pressed: turn on the LED 3) When the right button is pressed: turn off the LED Connect your wires to your circuit playground and test your code!

# Wiring External Buttons In the last lesson, we saw how you could use external components for **output**, like wiring up an LED. In this lesson, we'll see how you can use external components for **inputs**, like creating your own button "up" and "down" events. We'll start by using two wires connected to the `"A0"` and `"GND"` pins, like in the diagram to the right. When the wires are disconnected, it represents an "up" event or that the button isn't being pressed. When the wires are connected, it represents a "down" event or that the button has been pressed. # Do This 1. Make sure your Circuit Playground is disconnected from the computer 2. Grab two wires. 3. Connect one wire to the pin `"A0"`. 4. Connect the second wire to a `"GND"` pin. 5. Plug in your Circuit Playground. You may need to re-run the Maker Setup to make sure the board connects correctly. **Run the program!** With the program running, touch the unconnected ends of both wires together to "press" the button. When you do, the Circuit Playground should buzz!

# External Button Events This app shows how external buttons are created. This happens in two parts: 1. A [`createButton()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block lets you assign an external button to a variable 2. An [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][2] block uses the same variable name to detect button events like `up` and `down` Right now, the Circuit Playground makes a low-buzz when the wires touch for a `down` event. Let's add another event to make the Circuit Playground make a high-buzz when the wires release for an `up` event. # Do This
[expandable][3]
Click to Expand
1. Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][4] to detect when the `buzzButton` is released `up` - Add an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][5] block to your code - In the first parameter, do not select any of the options from the dropdown. Instead, type in `buzzButton` - In the second parameter, select "up" from the list of options 2. When the `buzzButton` is released: make a high-pitched buzz - Inside the [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][6]: - Use the [`buzzer.frequency()`(#f78183)][7] block to play a high-pitched buzz Run the program! The Circuit Playground should now make two buzzes - once when the wires touch, and again when the wires release

# Add Another External Button Let's add another external button to our device on pin `"A1"` that toggles the red LED on and off. This will only require **one** new wire connected to pin `"A1"` - to press the button, we can use the same `"GND"` wire from before. # Do This **Wiring Our Device:** 1. Disconnect your Circuit Playground from the computer 2. Connect another wire to pin `"A1"` 3. Reconnect your Circuit Playground to the computer. You may need to run the Maker Setup again. **Coding Your Device:** 1. Create a button variable on pin `"A1"` - Drag out a [`createButton()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block. - Name the variable `ledButton` - Change the pin to `"A1"` 2. Use an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][2] to detect when `ledButton` is pressed `down` - Drag out an [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][3]. - Set the component to `ledButton` by typing in the first parameter - Set the event to `"down"` 3. When `ledButton` is pressed: toggle the led - Use the [`led.toggle()`(#f78183)][4] block to make the red LED turn on and off **Run the program!** You should use the `"GND"` wire to switch between your two buttons - connecting it to the `buzzButton` should make the buzzer sounds from before, and connecting it to the `ledButton` should make the red LED turn on and off.

# Add an LED Let's update our device to toggle an external LED rather than the small red LED on the circuit playground! ## Do This **Wiring Our Device:** 1. Disconnect your Circuit Playground from the computer 2. Use two wires to connect an LED to the Circuit Playground on pin `"A6"` - One wire connects the negative (-) end of the LED to the `GND` pin - One wire connects the positive (+) end of the LED to the `"A6"` pin 3. Reconnect your Circuit Playground to the computer. You may need to run the Maker Setup again. **Coding Your Device:** 1. Create an LED variable on pin `"A6"` - Drag out a [`createLed()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block. - Change the pin to `"A6"` 2. Update the code to use the external LED instead of the small red led - Change into text mode - Update `led.toggle()` by replacing `led` with the name of your variable **Run the program!** You should use the `"GND"` wire to switch between your two buttons - connecting it to the `buzzButton` should make the buzzer sounds from before, and connecting it to the `ledButton` should make your external LED turn on and off

You may need to rerun the Maker Setup **Coding Your Device:** _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [Create three button variables on pins `"A4"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"`] - Drag out three [`createButton()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/applab/createButton/) blocks - Set their pins to `"A4"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"` ::: 2) ::: details [Use three `onBoardEvent()`(#f78183) blocks to detect when each of your buttons is `"down"`] - Drag out three [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) blocks - Type your button variables into the first parameter of each event - Set the event to "down" ::: 3) ::: details [Update the background color when a button is pressed] - Inside each [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/): - Use a [`setProperty()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setProperty/) block to change the background color to a color of your choosing ::: **Run Your Code!** You should be able to use the ground wire to press each of the buttons, which will update the background color of your app!

CSD U6 - Physical Input - PC_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app that uses 3 external buttons to play musical notes, like a mini piano
CSD U6 - Physical Input - PC_2222.long_instructions:
# Mini Piano

Create an app that uses 3 external buttons to play musical notes, like keys on a piano.

## Do This

**Wiring Your Device:**

1) Make sure your Circuit Playground is unplugged from the computer
2) Connect 3 wires to pins `"A1"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"`
3) Connect a wire to a `GND` pin
4) Plug your Circuit Playground back into the computer. You may need to rerun the Maker Setup

**Coding Your Device:**

1) ::: details [Create three button variables on pins `"A1"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"`]
	- Drag out three [`createButton()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/applab/createButton/) blocks
    - Set their pins to `"A1"`, `"A5"`, and `"A7"`
    :::

2) ::: details [Use three `onBoardEvent()`(#f78183) blocks to detect when each of your buttons is `"down"`]
	- Drag out three [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) blocks
    - Type your button variables into the first parameter of each event
	- Set the event to "down"
    :::
3) ::: details [When the button is pressed, play a note]
	- Inside each [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/):
    	- Use a [`buzzer.note()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/buzzer.note/) block to play a musical note of your choosing
    :::
    
**Run Your Code!** You should be able to use the ground wire to press each of the buttons, which will play a musical note!

CSD U6 - Physical Input - PA_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create an app that simulates a whack-a-mole game, where you press 3 external buttons to earn points
CSD U6 - Physical Input - PA_2222.long_instructions:
![expandable](https://images.code.org/8c543c31e6489b03c6d06e6d24b176e8-image-1650058131598.gif)
Click to Expand
# Whack-A-Mole Game Create an app that simulates a whack-a-mole game, where there are several animals that appear and you need to "bop" them to earn points. In this version, we'll use three external buttons to represent the animals. The user can use the `GND` wire to 'whack' each of the animals and generate points. The app has already been designed for you - your task is to wire up the device and keep track of the score using the Counter Pattern. ## Do This **Wiring Your Device:** 1) Make sure your Circuit Playground is unplugged from the computer 2) Connect 3 wires to pins `"A0"`, `"A4"`, and `"A5"` 3) Connect a wire to a `GND` pin 4) Plug your Circuit Playground back into the computer. You may need to rerun the Maker Setup **Coding Your Device:** 1) ::: details [Create three button variables on pins `"A0"`, `"A4"`, and `"A5"`] - Drag out three [`createButton()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/applab/createButton/) blocks - Set their pins to `"A4"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"` ::: 2) ::: details [Use three `onBoardEvent()`(#f78183) blocks to detect when each of your buttons is `"down"`] - Drag out three [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/) blocks - Type your button variables into the first parameter of each event - Set the event to "down" ::: 3) ::: details [When the user presses one of the animal buttons, increase their score] - Inside each [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)](/docs/applab/onBoardEvent/): - use the Counter Pattern to update the `score` variable. Each of the animal buttons should be worth a different amount of points - Use a [`setText()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setText/) block to update the score on the screen ::: **Run Your Code!** You should be able to use the ground wire to press each of the buttons, which will update the score on the screen.

contained levels.long_instructions: # Conductive Materials Our external buttons work because the alligator clips are made of metal, which **conducts electricity**. If you attach the clips to other items that conduct electricity, they can also work as buttons. For example, you can try paperclips or aluminum foil and the buttons will still work. ## Do This - Find materials around the classroom that you think will conduct electricity. Find at least 5 different types of items - Grab two wires and connect them to your Circuit Playground according to the code below so the button will work - Connect your items to the alligator clips and test your device. See which items are conductive and work as buttons, and which ones do not **Record your results in the box below!** Which items worked as buttons? Which ones didn't?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Escape Room

Pradnya is designing an app that can be used in an Escape Room, which is like a room with puzzles where you find clues to help you escape. The user will need to enter a 3 digit number in the app in order to win, which they can discover by finding 3 hidden buttons around the room. When the user presses a button, one of the digits is revealed. Once all 3 digits are revealed and the user types them into the app, they can escape!

Pradnya has already designed the app and created the code that checks for the correct 3-digit number, but she needs help hooking up the buttons and revealing the secret digits.

## Do This

1.  Wire up 3 buttons to pins `"A1"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"`, with a single ground wire to trigger each button
2.  Create three button variables on pins `"A1"`, `"A5"`, and `"A6"`
3.  Use three [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][0] blocks to detect when each of your buttons is "down"
4.  When the user presses a button, hide one of the `blueSquare` elements to reveal the secret digit underneath
    -   Use the [`hideElement()`(#fff176)][1] block to hide each of the `blueSquare` elements
    -   Example: `hideElement("blueSquare1")`

**Run the code!** Test that it works, revealing the secret three-digit code and viewing the win screen. The secret digits change every time, so you may need to test more than once.

You could also consider having students record a video of their app working and submitting it in addition to submitting their code.

CSD U6 - Physical Input - ChalA_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create a device prototype that simulates an event when two objects touch. For example, two people in love and, when they touch, the circuit playground turns red (to represent love)
CSD U6 - Physical Input - ChalA_2222.long_instructions:
# Physical Reactions

Create a device prototype that simulates an event when two objects touch. For example:

- Two people in love and, when they touch, the circuit playground turns red (to represent love)
- A blue paint brush and a yellow paint brush and, when they touch, the circuit playground turns green (to represent mixing colors)
- An oxygen atom and a carbon atom that, when they touch, the circuit playground buzzes (to represent a [Carbon Monoxide detector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_monoxide_detector))

You should use physical materials to create your two objects, such as creating figures out of cardboard or popsicle sticks. Your device should use two wires to represent buttons - when the wires touch, the circuit playground reacts.

This is a **prototype** for your device, which means it won't be perfect and will probably be a little messy. Instead, focus on demonstrating how all of the pieces would fit together to create your device.

## Do This

**Materials**

- Decide what reaction you would like to represent with this project. You can use one of the examples above, or create your own
- Design and decorate your two objects our of physical materials, like cardboard or paper or popsicle sticks.
- Attach a wire to each of your objects. Try to hide the wires so only the tips are visible for when they touch
- Prepare your circuit playground

**In Code Mode:**

1) Add code to detect when the two wires touch as a button event. When they do: have the circuit playground react (such as lighting up or making a sound)

**Run Your App!** Demonstrate your app for a peer and explain what it represents

CSD U6 - Physical Input - ChalB_2222.bubble_choice_description: Create a device prototype that simulates an alarm system that detects when someone opens a box.
CSD U6 - Physical Input - ChalB_2222.long_instructions:
# Alarm System Prototype

Create a device prototype that simulates an alarm system that detects when someone opens a box. This requires creating a box from physical materials like cardboard or paper, and attaching two wires to the inside of the box. When the box is closed, the wires should be touching. But when the box is open, the wires become disconnected and the circuit playground should buzz to warn that someone has opened the box.

This is a **prototype** for your device, which means it won't be perfect and will probably be a little messy. Instead, focus on demonstrating how all of the pieces would fit together to create your device.

## Do This

**Materials:**

- Create a box our of physical materials, like cardboard or a used tissue box. Design the box so it has a clear lid that can open and close in one place.
- Attach two wires to the inside of the box so that when the lid is closed, the wires are touching. You will probably need one wire on the underside of the lid, and another wire on the inside wall of the box.
- If necessary: cut small holes in the back of the box so the wires can run through and attach the circuit playground

**In Code Mode:**

1) Create a button variable
2) When the button is `down`: turn off the buzzer and all the lights on the circuit playground
3) When the button is `up`: turn on the buzzer and lights! Make a bunch of noise!

**Run the Code!** You could tell a friend that a treat is in the box and ask them to open it, only for them to be surprised when the alarm goes off!

CSD U6 - Physical Input - ChalC_2222.long_instructions:
![expandable](https://images.code.org/25cce8f702f27384b3042a6fcbc09803-image-1646938647982.png)
Image from Red Fern Electronics
# Create Your Own Button So far, we've simulated buttons by having two wires touch. Using other conductive materials, like paperclips or aluminum foil or metal tabs, we can simulate buttons or switches like we're more familiar with. This requires creating a situation where our two wires are close but not touching, then the user interacts with a third physical device which connects the two wires together simulating a button press. ## Do This **Prepare:** - Decide how you'd like to setup your button or switch. - You can search the internet for "DIY Switch" or "DIY Button" - Or, you can check out this guide from [Red Fern Electronics: DIY Switches](https://redfernelectronics.co.uk/diy-switches/) **Materials:** - Gather your conductive materials and wires together - Arrange your wires so they are close by, but not touching - Arrange your third conductive material so it can be pressed or toggled or moved to bridge the two other wires - Try to hide your wires as much as possible so only the button or switch is visible - Get your Circuit Playground ready **In Code Mode:** 1) Create a button variable 2) When the button is pressed: make a noise or light up 3) Attach your wires to your circuit playground and test your code **Run Your Code!** You should be able to press your button or toggle your switch like it's a real button or switch.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd6-2022/less.long_instructions:
# Design Your App

Use this level to add **design elements** to your app in Design Mode. Use the sketch from your Project Guide to add elements to the screen. Don't worry about adding code yet - you can do that in the next few levels.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Events

Add events to your app using [`onEvent()`(#fff176)][0] or [`onBoardEvent()`(#f78183)][1] blocks. Include other blocks that will let you test your events to make sure they are working correctly, such as changing the screen or making a small buzz on the circuit playground. Don't worry about any variables or if-statements for right now - you can do that in the next level.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Add Logic and Physical Materials

Add the core logic to your app, especially how your device uses inputs and outputs to function. Also start attaching your board to the physical materials you created. Your device should start to "merge together" with the physical materials you curated, and you may need to make small adjustments so things fit. Use your project guide to help complete your device. Test your app several times to see that it behaves as expected.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then Finish to continue to the next level

# Review Your App

Take a moment to review your app. Double-check that it meets all the requirements in the rubric - [click here to see the rubric][0]. Make any changes or updates you think are necessary, or you may decide that the app is fine.

Whenever your finished, press Run and then the purple Submit button to submit your project. Once you submit it, you won't be able to edit it.
